glsa.title: sudo: Privilege escalation
glsa.synopsis: A vulnerability in sudo allows local users to gain root privileges.

background.p: sudo (su “do”) allows a system administrator to delegate authority to give certain users (or groups of users) the ability to run some (or all) commands as root or another user while providing an audit trail of the commands and their arguments.

description.p: Qualys discovered a vulnerability in sudo’s get_process_ttyname() for Linux, that via sudo_ttyname_scan() can be directed to use a user-controlled, arbitrary tty device during its traversal of “/dev” by utilizing the world-writable /dev/shm.

impact.p: A local attacker can pretend that his tty is any character device on the filesystem, and after two race conditions, an attacker can pretend that the controlled tty is any file on the filesystem allowing for privilege escalation

workaround.p: There is no known workaround at this time.

resolution.p: All sudo users should upgrade to the latest version:
